confession.seduction_context: She had been angry after quarrelling with her children, and had gone to collect some wood

devil_mark.description: He removed something from her forehead, hurting her

confession.seduction_context: When looking for a lost cow near woods
Devil told him he was upset on account of his poverty, but he would make him rich
sabbat_activities: took no part and not stayed long

testimony.quarrel_subject: Water from bucket brought by Claudin

witnesses.name: Barbe femme à Anthoine Bon Jean

testimony.quarrel_subject: Bucket incident with mother and stepfather

harms_alleged.method_alleged: Something white in a paper dropped in water bucket
Something white in a paper dropped in water bucket

testimony.quarrel_subject: Mengin Badel had taken back a field
testimony.threat_quote: la premiere fois qu'il y yroit jamais n'en retourneroit pas sante

harms_alleged.harm_description: Illness so serious that he had to crawl back home; was ill on and off for two years before he died
harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: When Badel went to sow field

witnesses.name: Claude femme de Nicodemus Utchin
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: Nicodemus Utchin was porte enseigne de la prévôté de Chatenoy

harms_alleged.harm_description: Claudin had given him a 'loppin' he carried in his body, and of which he would die
Repeated suspicions even on his deathbed
Claudin told her husband was 'corrompu dedans luy'; made him a drink, promising to heal him for 'les fontaines' but he died 2 days before these

witnesses.name: Nicodemus Utchin
witnesses.occupation: porte enseigne de la prévôté de Chatenoy

harms_alleged.harm_description: Found a packet with something twisted inside it in the bucket of water
Had supper with them when he invited Claudin; Mengin died about a week later

testimony.quarrel_subject: Taking land from Claudin's adjoining field
testimony.threat_quote: par la mort dieu qu'il s'en repentiroit qu'il avoit ja un cheval boiteux et qu'il s'en trouveroit mal

harms_alleged.harm_description: Seemed to have difficulty with back legs, and two days later servant could hardly get it back from fields; shortly after had to be killed
harms_alleged.method_alleged: Claudin smacked mare on rump, saying it was a fine mare

harms_alleged.harm_description: 18 months later had another horse ill; Claudin told him he should obtain 'goutte de cheval', and bring 'fremis' from 'une champaigne'. It soon died
Mother asked Ambroise about it. She advised making it walk around church and giving it holy water, but he refused, and it died
Ambroise advised remedy but son refused since it was not 'chose decente ny propre à une beste de donner ce qu'apartient aux personnes'
Believed Claudin had caused death 2 years earlier
Called Margueritte to see sick cow, she put something in its mouth, but it still died
harms_alleged.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: Around same time Ambroise had come asking for alms

testimony.quarrel_subject: Ambroise had done weaving and witness accused her of keeping back yarn
testimony.threat_quote: Je prie que jamais tu ne puisse enfanter

harms_alleged.harm_description: Was pregnant at time, and subsequent labour was very painful
Later when pregnant again Ambroise touched her stomach in church, and she gave birth to a dead child

testimony.quarrel_subject: Claudin angry because when ploughing they turned plough on his adjoining land
testimony.threat_quote: Par la mort dieu que les gros guarioient tousjours les petits mais qu'ilz ne gaigneroient tousjours

harms_alleged.harm_description: Claudin looked at horses in pasture and remarked how well they were eating. On return one fell ill, and although Claudin gave it something it died 3 days later
Had serious chest illness after childbirth, only cured after making a pilgrimage
harms_alleged.precipitating_quarrel: Dispute over sheep confiscation and 5 francs payment

witnesses.name: Jalby femme de Jean Willaume le jeune

testimony.quarrel_subject: Refused to sell lard to Ambroise
testimony.threat_quote: she had not wanted to sell her any lard, but it would not profit her

harms_alleged.harm_description: Called in Ambroise, who said they must send an offering to St. Genens; cow recovered after this was done

Bewitched, losing her milk and having her body all twisted; Ambroise told her to spin a whole reel of thread at one go without speaking, then to wrap it around herself for 24 hours, make offering to St. Genens and promise pilgrimage. Did this and was healed

Husband had trouble with his leg, which was 'toute gastée'. Claudon Costelliere said Ambroise had done it by putting poison next to his bed. After various pilgrimages advised by Ambroise, he recovered

testimony.quarrel_subject: Claudin asked to buy barley, was refused

harms_alleged.harm_description: After drinking water from bucket near which Claudin sat, was suddenly taken with fever; died in 8 days
harms_alleged.method_alleged: Little 'drapeau' with something white inside it found in bucket

harms_alleged.harm_description: Died 4 days after Morisot

Around last Easter gave Margueritte alms, immediately afterwards fell ill, spending a month in bed. Margueritte came to visit and put hand on bed with mouth twisted up, 'faisant hideux regard', hand seemed to become white and shining. But husband said Margueritte had healed her, and she quickly recovered
Believed Margueritte had killed one little girl
Made another ill, as she still was
Margueritte came to tell him his mother had fallen in her kitchen as if dead. She had been ill for 8 days, then recovered, and claimed that Margueritte had given her the illness
Never been really well after illness, and had died previous winter

testimony.quarrel_subject: Uncle refused to sell Claudin 3 resaulx of oats

harms_alleged.harm_description: Uncle Anthoine Willaume had called Claudin to see young horse which was slightly injured. After refusing to sell oats, Claudin visited horse again before leaving, and it died later same day

testimony.quarrel_subject: Wife reproached Ambroise because her husband (weaver) had not kept 'fidel compte' of yarn
testimony.threat_quote: qu'elle ne peut jamais enfanter ce qu'elle portoit

harms_alleged.harm_description: Wife was pregnant and had long and painful labour, but finally pleased God that she was delivered safely
Claudin had been angry because they turned plough on his land, later admired horses, and one of them died a few days later
Had been so ill she expected to die, but Margueritte had cured her. Margueritte had been much around the house during her illness
Horse had a bad leg, and Ambroise advised wife to obtain holy water from St. Genove at Dollaincourt. When she washed the leg it fell off just below the knee as if it had been cut

Some 5 years earlier had been harvesting at Sendaincourt, about an hour after dawn, when he saw Claudin sit by a spring, and strike water several times with a stick. He then threw something in it as if he were sowing, taking it from his hat. After he had left a mist began to rise from the spring, then formed into a great cloud, from which it hailed heavily
harms_alleged.method_alleged: Striking water with stick and throwing something from hat

timeline.subject: Margueritte Gallier
timeline.details: Prévôt of Chatenoy asked by various inhabitants of La Neuveville to act against witches causing deaths and sicknesses among animals. Went to La Neuveville and interrogated Margueritte in house of Claude Uthin

timeline.subject: Margueritte Gallier
timeline.details: After making 'quelque difficulté', Margueritte confessed that she was a witch

timeline.subject: Hanriotte des Boeufs
timeline.details: Produced for interrogation. Initially denied, then confessed after being 'fort remonstrée'

timeline.subject: Hanriotte des Boeufs
timeline.details: Brought back to continue interrogation, she started to call on God, saying she was not a witch. Renewed admissions 15 minutes after being taken back to prison

timeline.subject: All 4 accused
timeline.details: Witnesses were apparently sought against all 4 suspects imprisoned at Chatenoy - Margueritte, Hanriotte, Claudin and Ambroise

timeline.subject: All 4 accused
timeline.details: Additional witnesses testified

timeline.subject: Margueritte Gallier
timeline.details: Confirmed earlier confessions, but would add no more, and now denied having killed small daughter of Jean Cabled

timeline.subject: Ambroise Gillot
timeline.details: Said she was about 46, native of Raymoix, daughter of Noel Thiebault, married to Gillot Gillot for some 17 years. Systematically denied charges but made some admissions about quarrels and remedies

timeline.subject: Claudin Clerget
timeline.details: Said he was about 50, native of Frey, son of Didier Clerject, blacksmith. Gave extensive biographical details. Systematically denied charges

timeline.subject: Margueritte vs Hanriotte
timeline.details: Hanriotte denied she was a witch, saying earlier confessions made out of fear. Rejected Margueritte's claim that she had been at sabbat

timeline.subject: Claudin vs witnesses
timeline.details: Claudin made various reproaches against witnesses

timeline.subject: Hanriotte, Claudin, Ambroise
timeline.details: PG des Vosges declares Margueritte sufficiently convicted by her own admissions. Other three should be put to torture, and while Ambroise was under torture Harriotte should be placed so she could hear 'les clameures des tortures'

timeline.subject: Claudin, Ambroise
timeline.details: Change de Nancy recommends that Margueritte and Harriotte should be interrogated again, and that Claudin and Ambroise be given 'question extraordinaire'

timeline.subject: Ambroise Gillot
timeline.details: Racked, placed on strappado with 50 pound weight, and given thumbscrews, whole torture lasting an hour. Stoutly denied all charges. Seems to have fainted towards end of torture

timeline.subject: Hanriotte des Boeufs
timeline.details: Immediately after Ambroise's torture. Renewed her confessions, said she had been to sabbat, where she had seen Margueritte and Claudon. Denied committing other malefices

timeline.subject: Claudin Clerget
timeline.details: Racked; endured for some time protesting, but finally began to confess. Admitted being seduced by Mre Persin 5 years earlier, going to sabbat, killing Gauthier couple with arsenic and devil's powder, killing Mengin Badel with arsenic, killing two horses with powder. Was trembling with 'une fievre froide', so was released

timeline.subject: Claudin Clerget
timeline.details: Escaped from chateau. Had broken his chains, climbed out of window, down roof of lean-to, and across moat. Suspected that guards from La Neuveville helped him

timeline.subject: Investigation of escape
timeline.details: Prévôt carried out enquiry into escape of Claudin. Guards seem to have been Jean Jacquinot and son of Mengin Ferry (latter probably nephew of Claudin's wife)

timeline.subject: Margueritte, Harriotte
timeline.details: PG des Vosges, Maimbourg, called for execution of Margueritte and Harriotte, and for further torture of Ambroise

timeline.subject: Margueritte Gallier
timeline.details: Change de Nancy agreed to death sentence for Margueritte, but asked for Harriotte to be interrogated further, and for Ambroise to be renvoyée jusqu'a rappel

timeline.subject: Ambroise vs Margueritte and Harriotte
timeline.details: Ambroise confronted with other two, who maintained that she was a witch

timeline.subject: Margueritte Gallier, Harriotte des Boeufs
timeline.details: They were taken away and executed

timeline.subject: Ambroise Gillot
timeline.details: After execution of other two, Ambroise was tortured on rack for half an hour, but would not confess

timeline.subject: Ambroise Gillot
timeline.details: PG des Vosges calls for Ambroise to be banished for life

timeline.subject: Ambroise Gillot
timeline.details: Court at Chatenois approves banishment sentence

accomplices_named.name: Claudon Costelliere
accomplices_named.context: Named by Ambroise as someone who wanted to lead her and 'la faire perdre'; suspected of witchcraft; absent from La Neufville

accomplices_named.name: Jehan Rouyer
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat by Claudin (confession under torture)

accomplices_named.name: Jaccotte
accomplices_named.context: Woman seen at sabbat by Claudin (confession under torture)

notable_quotes.speaker: Jeannon femme à Nicolas Deny (witness 3)
notable_quotes.french: la premiere fois qu'il y yroit jamais n'en retourneroit pas sante
notable_quotes.context: Claudin's threat to Mengin Badel about the field

notable_quotes.speaker: Didiere veuve de Jean Grinsenot (witness 16)
notable_quotes.french: Par la mort dieu que les gros guarioient tousjours les petits mais qu'ilz ne gaigneroient tousjours
notable_quotes.context: Claudin's threat when angry about ploughing on his land

notable_quotes.speaker: Ambroise Gillot
notable_quotes.french: Je prie que jamais tu ne puisse enfanter
notable_quotes.context: Threat/curse to Yzabel wife of Adam Varin over yarn dispute

notable_quotes.speaker: Cleron femme de Florentin Moictessier (witness 14)
notable_quotes.french: que c'estoit une meschante femme et que le diable la seduisoit ou la vouloit seduire et qu'il failloit prier Dieu
notable_quotes.context: Warning to Ambroise when she complained of something pushing against her ear

notable_quotes.speaker: Ambroise Gillot
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle estoit telle qu'elle pouvoit estre
notable_quotes.context: Response when told she was a bad woman

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine femme à Jean Cabled (witness 22)
notable_quotes.french: meschante femme qu'est ce que vous me faict retirez vous arriere de moy vous m'engenoche
notable_quotes.context: Catherine's accusation when Margueritte visited her while sick

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudin Clerget
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle mesme ne se damnat et qu'elle n'y estoit esté
notable_quotes.context: Claudin to Margueritte during confrontation, telling her she should not damn herself and she was not at sabbat

notable_quotes.speaker: Ambroise Gillot (during torture)
notable_quotes.french: they were killing her, that they were damaging her limbs, and that she would never be able to work again
notable_quotes.context: Cried out during torture but stoutly denied all charges

notable_quotes.speaker: Florentin Moictessier (witness 10)
notable_quotes.french: par la mort dieu qu'il s'en repentiroit qu'il avoit ja un cheval boiteux et qu'il s'en trouveroit mal
notable_quotes.context: Claudin's threat to Jean Ferry about ploughing help

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengin Michiel (witness 26)
notable_quotes.french: qu'on parloit fort d'elle mais qu'elle scavoit bien quand on en parloit en mal et en bien
notable_quotes.context: Ambroise told him she knew when people spoke of her, good or bad

relationships.evidence_text: Hanriotte veuve Jean des Boeufs, married 33 years before with Jehan de Boeuf of Viocourt
daughter of Thouvenet Gardene of La Neufville
Ferry persuaded him to come back to La Neufville with him, and marry his sister Margueritte, widow of Jean Lietard
married to Gillot Gillot for some 17 years

relationships.person2: Barbe femme à Anthoine Bon Jean

relationships.person1: Barbe femme à Anthoine Bon Jean
relationships.evidence_text: He was regular visitor to house, since he had married the widow of the witness's brother
before her marriage, she had been servant to Adam Varin
Morisot Gauthier and his wife Barbe

harms_catalog.harm_description: Made ill with powder after refusing alms; Margueritte wished to heal her but master had not given her white powder
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: A week after seduction by devil

harms_catalog.victim_name: Baby of Jean Cabled and Catherine
harms_catalog.harm_description: Lifted cover over cradle, asked how baby was, and put a 'malediction' on it. Baby died 4 or 6 weeks later
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Catherine had told her off for not producing enough spinning, although she paid her as normal

harms_catalog.victim_name: Cow belonging to Claudon daughter of Jean Limosin
harms_catalog.harm_description: Put powder on cow and it soon died
Made ill when she refused alms, but cured her a fortnight later
Hanriotte would only admit to killing one of her own geese
Died some 6 years before within 15 days after drinking water from bucket brought by Claudin. Found something white in a paper in bucket
harms_catalog.method_alleged: something white in a paper dropped in water bucket

harms_catalog.harm_description: Died some 6 years before within 15 days after drinking water from bucket. Something white in paper found in bucket
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Refused to give Claudin barley, invited him to dine
harms_catalog.method_alleged: arsenic and devil's powder in bucket (per Claudin's torture confession)

harms_catalog.harm_description: Illness so serious he had to crawl back home; was ill on and off for two years before he died. Carried a 'loppin' in his body
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Mengin Badel had taken back a field from Claudin
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: When Badel went to sow field

harms_catalog.harm_description: Bought at St. Dié, had been ploughing. After quarrel with Claudin who smacked mare on rump, seemed to have difficulty with back legs, two days later servant could hardly get it back from fields; shortly after had to be killed
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Utchin's wife Thomasse told witness to take small amount from adjoining land of Claudin, who had taken too much
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: two days later showed difficulty, shortly after had to be killed

harms_catalog.harm_description: 18 months after mare incident, had another horse ill. Claudin told him he should obtain 'goutte de cheval' and bring 'fremis' from 'une champaigne'. When he objected this was too difficult, Claudin said it was only way to cure horse - it soon died
Some 2 years earlier had sick horse. His mother asked Ambroise about it. She advised making it walk around church and giving it holy water, but he refused this advice, and it died

Claudin had been angry because when ploughing they turned plough on his adjoining land. Some 3 or 4 days later took horses to pasture, where Claudin looked at them and remarked how well they were eating. On return one fell ill, and although Claudin gave it something it died 3 days later
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: They turned plough on Claudin's adjoining land
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: 3 or 4 days to pasture incident, then 3 days to death

harms_catalog.harm_description: Had serious chest illness after childbirth, only cured after making a pilgrimage
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Dispute over sheep confiscation and refused to pay 5 francs

harms_catalog.harm_description: Was pregnant at time, and subsequent labour was very painful
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Ambroise had done weaving and witness accused her of keeping back yarn

harms_catalog.harm_description: Later when pregnant again Ambroise touched her stomach as she stood talking to Jean Cabled's wife in the church, and she gave birth to a dead child

harms_catalog.victim_name: Cow of Cleron femme de Florentin Moictessier
harms_catalog.harm_description: Around same time Ambroise had come asking for alms, had a cow sick, which she believed to be Margueritte's doing; called her to see it, and she put something in its mouth, but it still died
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Context of Ambroise asking for alms

harms_catalog.victim_name: Calf of Esdeline femme de Mongin Ferry
harms_catalog.harm_description: About 8 days later lost a calf
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Refused to sell lard to Ambroise

harms_catalog.harm_description: Later had a cow sick, called in Ambroise, who said they must send an offering to St. Genens; cow recovered after this was done

Bewitched, losing her milk and having her body all twisted; went to see Ambroise who told her to spin a whole reel of thread at one go without speaking, then wrap it around herself for 24 hours, make offering to St. Genens and promise pilgrimage. Did this and was healed

harms_catalog.victim_name: Husband of Jannotte femme de Mongin Ferry (witness 20)
harms_catalog.harm_description: Husband had trouble with his leg, which was 'toute gastée'. Claudon Costelliere said Ambroise had done it by putting poison next to his bed. After various pilgrimages advised by Ambroise, he recovered
harms_catalog.method_alleged: putting poison next to his bed

harms_catalog.harm_description: Around last Easter gave Margueritte alms, immediately afterwards fell ill, spending a month in bed. Margueritte came to visit and put hand on bed with mouth twisted up, 'faisant hideux regard', hand seemed to become white and shining. Husband said Margueritte had healed her, and she quickly recovered
Believed Margueritte had killed one little girl
Made another ill, as she still was

Some 3 years earlier Margueritte came to tell him his mother had fallen in her kitchen as if dead. She had been ill for 8 days, then recovered, and claimed that Margueritte had given her the illness. Never been really well afterwards, and died previous winter

Uncle had called Claudin to see young horse which was slightly injured. Afterwards went to drink in tavern and Claudin asked to buy 3 resaulx of oats, which uncle refused. Did this 2 or 3 times, then Claudin told him he would repent. He visited horse again before leaving, and it died later same day
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Uncle refused to sell 3 resaulx of oats

harms_catalog.harm_description: Wife was pregnant and had long and painful labour after Ambroise's curse, but finally pleased God that she was delivered safely
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Wife reproached Ambroise because her husband (weaver) had not kept 'fidel compte' of yarn

harms_catalog.harm_description: Claudin had been angry because they turned plough on his land, later admired horses, and one of them died a few days later
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: They turned plough on Claudin's land

harms_catalog.harm_description: Previous year had been so ill she expected to die, but Margueritte had cured her. Margueritte had been much around the house during her illness

Some 6 weeks earlier horse had a bad leg, and Ambroise advised wife to obtain holy water from St. Genove at Dollaincourt, with which she should wash the leg. When she did so it fell off just below the knee as if it had been cut
Leg fell off just below knee as if it had been cut

Some 5 years earlier witness had been harvesting at Sendaincourt, about an hour after dawn, when he saw Claudin sit by a spring, and strike water several times with a stick. He then threw something in it as if he were sowing, taking it from his hat. After he had left a mist began to rise from the spring, then formed into a great cloud, from which it hailed heavily. No-one dared use the spring for more than a year
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Striking water with stick and throwing something from hat into spring

material_culture.context: Margueritte said her powder was in a 'chappeau d'estain' on windowsill in barn. When brought, found to contain two little packets of cabbage seed, and an empty packet from which she said the powder must have escaped
Found in pewter hat on windowsill instead of magical powder
Devil gave Margueritte grey powder (to harm) and white powder (to heal)
Claudin allegedly dropped something white in a paper into water bucket, causing deaths of Barbe and Marisot Gauthier
9 years before Claudin had stolen a pistol from Nicodemus Utchin's house, sold it at Frain. Utchin bought it back for 4 francs, plus 2 francs of wine to find out who was thief
Claudin asked to buy a bichot of barley from Morisot; was refused but eventually given it
Esdeline's husband had bought some lard, Ambroise came asking if she would sell her some. Refused but gave her a good piece. Returned next day and repeated request, but was refused absolutely
Repeatedly mentioned as remedy and protection. Ambroise threw quantities of holy water at devil to drive him off. Used from various saints (St. Genens, St. Genot, St. Genove at Dollaincourt)

Margueritte had been spinning for Cabled's wife Catherine. Ambroise had done weaving and was accused of keeping back yarn. Esdeline told to spin whole reel of thread at one go without speaking as remedy
Ambroise advised Esdeline to bathe using 'bonnes herbes de St. Jean'
Ambroise used cloth soaked in holy water, which she put on forehead to preserve 'cresme' she had from baptism, for a fortnight
Claudin confessed under torture to using arsenic to kill Gauthier couple and Mengin Badel
Claudin suggested in his defense that Francois Marchal had used sulphur on a horse, thrown it away through kitchen window, it fell in bucket, and would flare up when put on fire
Claudin asked to buy this from Anthoine Willaume, was refused
Nicodemus Utchin paid 2 francs of wine to find out who was thief of his pistol
Claudin had broken his chains when he escaped from the chateau

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial and residence of most accused and witnesses
Seat of prévôté, where trials were held and prisoners kept
Seat of Change de Nancy (appellate court); Claudin spent a year there as youth in service of baker; his uncle Demenge Clerject lived in faubourg of Nancy
Claudin's birthplace
Ambroise's birthplace
Origin of Hanriotte's husband Jehan de Boeuf
Claudin went as 'pallefrenier' for 14 months
Where Claudin returned to blacksmithing for 5 months and married first wife Barbon
Near where Claudin joined company of M. de Clermont d'Antraigues
Claudin went to Poland with Henri III, serving as a smith
Where Claudin sold stolen pistol
Where Claudin and Jean Ferry were arrested during an 'entreprinse'
Where Florentin Moictessier bought a fine mare
Where Dedier Liermey was harvesting when he saw Claudin making hail at a spring; also home of Jean Willaume surnomme Brancquebourg
Where widow Martinotte lived (taught Ambroise remedies); where Jehan Rouyer lived (allegedly seen at sabbat)
Location of St. Genove holy water source
Where Claudin's daughter by first wife was in service
Where one of Hanriotte's daughters lived
Home of Claudin Gardeme dit Harbel
Home of Claudon Chrestien
Where Claudin allegedly made hail by striking water with stick and throwing something from his hat
Where Ambroise touched Yzabel's stomach, leading to stillbirth; where Ambroise suggested sick horse should walk around
Pilgrimage site recommended by Ambroise for offerings
Pilgrimage site recommended by Ambroise
Pilgrimage site mentioned in testimony
Pilgrimage site recommended by Ambroise
Where Claudin was imprisoned and from which he escaped; where Francois Marchal had escaped from previously
Unspecified location where Margueritte, Hanriotte, and Claudin allegedly attended sabbat and saw each other and other witches
Where Hanriotte was looking for lost cow when devil appeared; where Margueritte was collecting wood when seduced
Where much of the ploughing disputes occurred; where Claudin admired horses before they fell ill

historical_context.military_details: Duc Casimir's troops were lodged in village some 10 or 11 years earlier. Claudin showed special knowledge of movement of these troops. Claudin also went to Poland with Henri III, serving as a smith
weather_events: Hail produced by Claudin at spring near Sendaincourt, witnessed by Dedier Liermey
economic_hardship_indicators: Claudin's poverty mentioned as reason for devil's seduction
Barbe wife of Anthoine Bon Jean had married a man less well off than herself, who had consumed her inheritance, so that she was dependent on her mother
Disputes over barley, oats, lard, yarn suggesting scarcity
Ambroise asking for alms to help make pilgrimage
religious_calendar_references: last St. Remy (when Margueritte was seduced)
Wednesday of Holy Week (when Claudin came to buy barley from Morisot)
last Easter (when Catherine gave Margueritte alms and fell ill)
les fontaines (religious celebration Claudin promised to heal Mengin Badel for)

officials_named.name: Claude Uthin
officials_named.description: hostellier and substitut of the PG des Vosges

officials_named.name: Nicodemus Utchin
officials_named.description: porte enseigne de la prévôté de Chatenoy

officials_named.name: Maimbourg
officials_named.description: PG des Vosges who called for execution on 7 August

officials_named.name: M. Petitgot
officials_named.description: lieutenant general des Vosges who conducted inquiry for Claudin's remission after killing Claudon Chrestien

prior_legal_disputes.description: Some 6 years earlier Claudin had become involved in a quarrel between Claudin Gardeme dit Harbel of Bouxey and Claudon Chrestien of Vomecourt; latter had been determined to attack him, and in self-defence Claudin had thrown a stone which struck him on the forehead, from which wound he died 2 days later
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: Had petitioned duke for remission, which had been granted after enquiry by M. Petitgot, lieutenant general des Vosges. Letters patent were in hands of his uncle Demenge Clerject

prior_legal_disputes.description: 9 years before Claudin had stolen a pistol from Nicodemus Utchin's house, and sold it at Frain
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: Utchin bought it back for 4 francs, plus 2 francs of wine to find out who was thief. (Claudin claimed he had borrowed it and used it as surety for debt)

prior_legal_disputes.description: Previous year Vincent Badel had made a report to the substitut Claude Utchin that Claudin was taking unfair advantage of some meadows he held for wards
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: Witness claimed it had been a true report

prior_legal_disputes.description: Francois Marchal had escaped from château of Chatenois

legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Claudin was able to escape by breaking his chains, climbing out of window, down roof of lean-to, and across moat, though he was still suffering from after-effects of torture. Guards were from La Neuveville and one was close relative (nephew of Claudin's wife)

hearsay_chains.content: Told her that Claudin had given him a 'loppin' he carried in his body, and of which he would die
Repeated suspicions even on his deathbed
Told her that Claudin had offered to make him a drink to cure him
Told him of finding a packet with something twisted inside it in the bucket of water
Asked him to have supper with them when he invited Claudin
When she accused Claudon of causing husband's leg illness, Claudon said Ambroise had done it by putting poison next to his bed
Told her children when ill that Margueritte had cured her
Uncle was astonished after horse died, and regretted refusing Claudin the oats, believing that he had killed the horse
Heard later from others that Claudin had made threats against her

emotional_state_notes: Hanriotte was 'fort remonstrée' before confessing, then retracted
Ambroise 'stoutly denied all charges' even under torture, cried out that they were killing her, damaging her limbs, and she would never be able to work again
Claudin 'trembling all over with une fievre froide' after torture
Margueritte 'seemed the more sure of herself' during confrontation with Claudin

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Vincent Badel had made a false report to the substitut Claude Utchin that he was taking unfair advantage of some meadows he held for wards
Reproached Vincent's wife Claudon that she had previously served her father-in-law Claude Badel who 'paillardoit' with her, then married her to his son
Said that the curé of la Neufville had 'tenue et paillardé' Claude wife of Nicodemus Utchin
Nicodemus himself had made an 'esgout de chaulette' which fell on the roof of Claudin's house and damaged it
Reproached Nicolas Denys with being 'homme querelleux'
Jean Ferry had been called thief by wife of Denys
Philippe widow of Mengin Badel had taken some of his hay
Didiere widow of Jean Grinsenot had not paid him what she owed for sheep he had looked after for her
Accused Claudon wife of Jean Ferry of keeping property belonging to her wards

Accused of stealing a shroud and a shirt, and of having taken property belonging to her nephew after her mother's death. Claimed Claudin offered to give her something to put beneath husband's pillow to kill him, and wanted to have her

Francois Marchal had escaped from château of Chatenois, had 'despendu son bien malheureusement', and had stolen items from the inheritance of his sister. Suggested he had used sulphur on horse which fell in bucket and caused flare-up
Accused Dedier Liermey of having stolen a resal of wheat some years earlier

third_parties.name: Claudon Cottelier (Costelliere)
third_parties.context: Now absent from La Neufville, suspected of witchcraft, allegedly wanted to lead Ambroise with her. Accused by Jannotte of causing her husband's leg illness (though Claudon blamed Ambroise)

third_parties.name: Martinotte
third_parties.context: Widow who lived at Houecourt; taught Ambroise the yarn remedy

third_parties.name: Jehan Rouyer
third_parties.context: Of Houecourt, allegedly seen at sabbat by Claudin (confession under torture)

third_parties.name: Jaccotte
third_parties.context: Woman of la Neufville, allegedly seen at sabbat by Claudin (confession under torture)

third_parties.name: Jean Jacquinot
third_parties.context: One of two guards of Claudin, from La Neuveville, suspected of helping him escape

third_parties.name: Son of Mengin Ferry
third_parties.context: One of two guards of Claudin, close relative, suspected of helping him escape

third_parties.name: Demenge Clerject
third_parties.context: Living in faubourg of Nancy, holding Claudin's letters patent for remission

third_parties.name: Barbon
third_parties.context: Daughter of Jean Nacquart, Claudin married her at Mattaincourt and lived with her for 12 years

third_parties.name: Daughter of Claudin and Barbon
third_parties.context: In service at Vallerois le Secque

third_parties.name: M. de Clermont d'Antraigues
third_parties.context: Claudin joined his company near Paris

third_parties.name: M. de Bouzey
third_parties.context: Gentleman whom Claudin and Jean Ferry accompanied on an 'entreprinse' until arrested at Chaumont

third_parties.name: Jean Gilbert
third_parties.context: Of La Neufville, met Claudin at Mattaincourt

third_parties.name: Claudin Gardeme dit Harbel
third_parties.context: Of Bouxey, involved in quarrel that led to Claudin killing Claudon Chrestien

third_parties.name: Claudon Chrestien
third_parties.context: Of Vomecourt, killed by Claudin 6 years earlier in self-defense (stone to forehead); Claudin received ducal remission

third_parties.name: Anthoine Willaume
third_parties.context: Owned young horse that died after Claudin was refused oats

third_parties.name: Jannotte Boubier
third_parties.context: Had been ill and claimed Margueritte had cured her

third_parties.name: Thomasse wife of Utchin
third_parties.context: Told Florentin Moictessier to take small amount from adjoining land of Claudin

third_parties.name: Curé of la Neufville
third_parties.context: Claudin accused him of misconduct with Claude wife of Nicodemus Utchin (she denied)

third_parties.name: Henri III
third_parties.context: Claudin went to Poland with Henri III, serving as a smith

third_parties.name: Duke (of Lorraine)
third_parties.context: Claudin petitioned duke for remission after killing Claudon Chrestien; Claudin's goods had been confiscated by officers of duke after murder

extraction_metadata.notes: This is an exceptionally complex trial involving 4 accused individuals with extensive witness testimony (30 witnesses). Margueritte and Hanriotte were executed on 13 August 1586. Claudin escaped on 26 July 1586 after confessing under torture. Ambroise was banished for life on 1 September 1586 after withstanding torture twice without confessing. The trial provides rich detail on quarrels, maleficia, social relationships, legal procedures, defense strategies, and the dynamics between the accused. Notable features include Claudin's elaborate biographical account, Ambroise's steadfast resistance to torture, the escape inquiry, and extensive reproaches against witnesses.
